docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who endured a major political setback as first lady when she tried to promote universal health care, revived that crusade yesterday but in a more measured way, offering a plan to reduce costs, through programs like disease prevention, to make universal coverage affordable. Mrs. Clinton, who is seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, said she would cut health care spending by $120 billion a year through prevention programs, coordinated treatment of chronic diseases and computerized record keeping.

headline.main: Clinton Revisits Health Care and Affordability

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer said yesterday that he would start negotiations over next year’s budget in November, two months earlier than is traditional in Albany, arguing that an early start would allow more of the talks to be public and minimize the last-minute horse trading that has hampered the budget process in the past.

headline.main: Spitzer Says He Will Start Budget Talks 60 Days Early
headline.print_headline: Spitzer Says He Will Start Budget Talks 60 Days Early

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of children in New Jersey without health insurance increased 37 percent from 2000 to 2005, compared with a 9 percent decrease nationwide, according to a study released yesterday by New Jersey Policy Perspective, a group that monitors state issues. The increase was greatest for black and Hispanic children. It came even though New Jersey spends about $1 billion annually on a program called FamilyCare that covers 530,000 children. The governor’s budget proposal calls for providing health insurance to 68,000 more children next year.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Confronted too often with the sentiment so succinctly expressed by Nicholas D. Kristof when he writes that ''even if a single-payer system isn't politically possible right now'' (''A Short American Life,'' column, May 21), I can't help but wonder what makes us different from the other developed nations that made the successful transition to national universal health care systems.

headline.main: On Health Care, A Can-Do Attitude

docs.abstract: Three letters comment on Nicholas D Kristof May 21 Op-Ed column on health care reform; Ted Herman deplores nation's inability to move toward universal health care system; Dr Quentin D Young says time is running out for finding Medicare-for-all solution; Dan Leonard (America's Health Insurance Plans) says health insurance plans are continuing their longstanding efforts to ensure that all Americans have access to quality, affordable health care coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the health care industry's perception of Michael Moore's new movie, ''Sicko,'' misstated the educational affiliation of Elizabeth Teisberg, the co-author of a recent book, ''Redefining Health Care.'' She is an associate professor at the Darden School of Business at the University of Virginia, not an economist at Stanford University.
docs.abstract: Correction on May 22 article about health care industry's perception of Michael Moore's new movie Sicko
